titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Betty Zane Grosso Collection of Zane and Dolly Grey Papers
Betty Zane Grosso Collection of Zane and Dolly Grey Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:38

did.unittitle: Betty Zane Grosso collection of Zane and Dolly Grey papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection documents the life and work of the American writer Zane Grey and his wife Dolly Grey, and to some extent the lives of their children. The papers chiefly consist of correspondence between Zane and Dolly Grey from the time they met until his death, circa 1900-1939. Their letters document Zane Grey's frequent travels throughout the American West and in the South Pacific, his career as a writer, their marriage, and the growth of their family. The collection also includes some correspondence with others; a draft of Zane Grey's autobiography; Dolly Grey's diaries; photographs and ephemera; and ten films. Many of the films apparently document hunting and fishing expeditions, but the collection also includes a print of the 1936 Australian film "White Death," in which Grey was featured as himself, and two documentaries about Zane Grey produced in 1985 by his family.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Serendipity Books on the Frederick W. and Carrie S. Beinecke Fund for Western Americana, 2002-2003; Gift of Gary and Bridget McMahon, 2003; purchased from William Reese Company, 2010.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 10-17 (motion picture film): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 8 (VHS cassettes): Use of originals is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Betty Zane Grosso Collection of Zane and Dolly Grey Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Betty Zane Grosso Collection of Zane and Dolly Grey Papers. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit. This collection was rehoused into standard archival containers and listed as each accession was acquired. In 2011, the accessions were merged and organized into series.
Formerly classed as Uncat MSS 261, Uncat MSS 529, Uncat MSS 542, and Uncat MSS 1253.

bioghist.head: Zane and Dolly Grey
bioghist.p: Zane Grey, writer of popular adventure stories about the American West, was born Pearl Zane Gray in Zanesville, Ohio, in 1872, to Lewis M. Gray, a dentist, and Josephine Zane Gray. Changing his name to Zane Grey in early adulthood, he studied dentistry at the University of Pennsylvania, graduating in 1896, and started his own practice in New York City. In November 1905 he married Lina Elise Roth, known as Dolly, a graduate of Hunter College. The couple settled in Lackawaxen, Pennsylvania, where they began a family that grew to include three children: Romer (1909-1976), Betty (1912-2007), and Loren (1915-2007). Dolly Grey strongly supported her husband's ambitions to make his living as a writer, helping to edit his work and manage his career as he became increasingly successful. Despite his long absences from home and several acknowledged extramarital affairs, their marriage remained strong and Dolly Grey continued to champion Zane Grey's work following his death of heart failure in 1939.

Zane Grey's prolific output included best-selling novels such as Riders of the Purple Sage , The Lone Star Ranger, and Under the Tonto Rim, many of which were made into equally successful Hollywood films. Grey lived the adventurous life he wrote about, spending months of each year camping in the Arizona desert or fishing off Tahiti and Australia. He was as famous for fishing as he was for writing about it, holding a number of world records including a 1,036-pound tiger shark.

Dolly Grey died in 1957 at the age of 74 in Altadena, California, where the family had moved circa 1920. She was buried beside her husband in Lackawaxen, Pennsylvania. After her death the Grey children continued stewardship of their father's legacy through management of Zane Grey, Inc., formed in 1933 to manage Grey's assets and the rights to his work. In 1931 Betty Zane Grey married Robert W. Carney, with whom she had two daughters; she married George D. Grosso in 1951.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection documents the life and work of the American writer Zane Grey and his wife Dolly Grey, and to some extent the lives of their children. The papers chiefly consist of correspondence between Zane and Dolly Grey from the time they met until his death, circa 1900-1939. Their letters document Zane Grey's frequent travels throughout the American West and in the South Pacific, his career as a writer, their marriage, and the growth of their family. The collection also includes some correspondence with others; a draft of Zane Grey's autobiography; Dolly Grey's diaries; photographs and ephemera; and ten films. Many of the films apparently document hunting and fishing expeditions, but the collection also includes a print of the 1936 Australian film "White Death," in which Grey was featured as himself, and two documentaries about Zane Grey produced in 1985 by his family.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Correspondence, 1900-1969. II. Writings, 1906-1938. III. Dolly Grey Diaries, 1906-1954. IV. Other Papers, 1905-1950. V. Audiovisual Materials, 1935-1985.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Zane Grey to Dolly Grey, Dolly Grey to Zane Grey, and Other Correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists chiefly of correspondence between Zane and Dolly Grey. It also includes letters to Zane and Dolly Grey from family, friends, publishers, and fans. A small amount of correspondence to Betty Zane Grosso is also present.
Dolly Grey's letters to her husband often enclose correspondence from third parties to Zane Grey, bearing her own annotations, as well as snapshots of their children.

did.unittitle: Grosso, George, to Betty Zane Grosso
Kerr, Christopher to Betty Zane Grosso
Witt, Diane Gray to Betty Zane Grosso

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II contains writings of Zane Grey, including a typescript draft of his unfinished autobiography, a notebook in which he discusses writing style, and two untitled short pieces.

did.unittitle: "The Living Past: The Autobiography of Zane Grey", typescript carbon
"One of Dad's description of women," autograph manuscript

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Dolly Grey's diaries. The first volume documents the first year of her marriage, after which there is a large gap. The rest of the diaries chronicle her daily life from 1924 to 1939, and then with gaps from 1940 to 1954.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged roughly by type of material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV contains photographs of Zane Grey including formal portraits, images of him camping and fishing, and images of the Grey family, including some publicity photos taken some time after Zane Grey's death. The series also contains miscellaneous other papers such as clippings, notes, shopping lists, writings by Dolly Grey and Betty Zane Grosso, and a reflection about Zane Grey by a college classmate.

did.unittitle: "Zane Grey the Man" by Wiborn, typescript carbon, corrected
Postcards, bookmark with Zane Grey portrait
Poems by Dolly Grey and Betty Zane Grosso
Documents regarding claim against McClure's Magazaine
Poster: "Sol Lesser presents Zane Grey (himself) in South Sea Adventures"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of eight reels of film including home movies of the Grey family, footage of Grey in Australia and New Zealand, and the commercial film "White Death." It also includes two documentary films in the VHS format apparently made by Gary McMahon, husband of Betty Zane Grosso's granddaughter Bridget Kerr McMahon.
